text_entry: ACT I
SCENE I. London. The palace.
Enter KING HENRY, LORD JOHN OF LANCASTER, the EARL of WESTMORELAND, SIR WALTER BLUNT, and others

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: So shaken as we are, so wan with care,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Find we a time for frighted peace to pant,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: And breathe shortwinded accents of new broils

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: To be commenced in strands afar remote.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: No more the thirsty entrance of this soil

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Shall daub her lips with her own childrens blood

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Nor more shall trenching war channel her fields,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Nor bruise her flowerets with the armed hoofs

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Of hostile paces: those opposed eyes,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Which, like the meteors of a troubled heaven,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: All of one nature, of one substance bred,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Did lately meet in the intestine shock

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: And furious close of civil butchery

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Shall now, in mutual wellbeseeming ranks,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: March all one way and be no more opposed

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Against acquaintance, kindred and allies:

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: The edge of war, like an illsheathed knife,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: No more shall cut his master. Therefore, friends,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: As far as to the sepulchre of Christ,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Whose soldier now, under whose blessed cross

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: We are impressed and engaged to fight,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Forthwith a power of English shall we levy

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Whose arms were moulded in their mothers womb

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: To chase these pagans in those holy fields

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Over whose acres walkd those blessed feet

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Which fourteen hundred years ago were naild

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: For our advantage on the bitter cross.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: But this our purpose now is twelve month old,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: And bootless tis to tell you we will go:

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Therefore we meet not now. Then let me hear

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Of you, my gentle cousin Westmoreland,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: What yesternight our council did decree

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: In forwarding this dear expedience.

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: My liege, this haste was hot in question,

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: And many limits of the charge set down

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: But yesternight: when all athwart there came

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: A post from Wales loaden with heavy news

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Whose worst was, that the noble Mortimer,

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Leading the men of Herefordshire to fight

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Against the irregular and wild Glendower,

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Was by the rude hands of that Welshman taken,

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: A thousand of his people butchered

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Upon whose dead corpse there was such misuse,

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Such beastly shameless transformation,

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: By those Welshwomen done as may not be

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Without much shame retold or spoken of.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: It seems then that the tidings of this broil

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Brake off our business for the Holy Land.

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: This matchd with other did, my gracious lord

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: For more uneven and unwelcome news

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Came from the north and thus it did import:

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: On Holyrood day, the gallant Hotspur there,

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Young Harry Percy and brave Archibald,

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: That evervaliant and approved Scot,

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: At Holmedon met,

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Where they did spend a sad and bloody hour,

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: As by discharge of their artillery,

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: And shape of likelihood, the news was told

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: For he that brought them, in the very heat

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: And pride of their contention did take horse,

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Uncertain of the issue any way.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Here is a dear, a true industrious friend,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Sir Walter Blunt, new lighted from his horse.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Staind with the variation of each soil

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Betwixt that Holmedon and this seat of ours

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: And he hath brought us smooth and welcome news.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: The Earl of Douglas is discomfited:

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Ten thousand bold Scots, two and twenty knights,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Balkd in their own blood did Sir Walter see

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: On Holmedons plains. Of prisoners, Hotspur took

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Mordake the Earl of Fife, and eldest son

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: To beaten Douglas and the Earl of Athol,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Of Murray, Angus, and Menteith:

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: And is not this an honourable spoil

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: A gallant prize ha, cousin, is it not

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: In faith,

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: It is a conquest for a prince to boast of.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Yea, there thou makest me sad and makest me sin

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: In envy that my Lord Northumberland

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Should be the father to so blest a son,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: A son who is the theme of honours tongue

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Amongst a grove, the very straightest plant

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Who is sweet Fortunes minion and her pride:

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Whilst I, by looking on the praise of him,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: See riot and dishonour stain the brow

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Of my young Harry. O that it could be proved

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: That some nighttripping fairy had exchanged

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: In cradleclothes our children where they lay,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: And calld mine Percy, his Plantagenet!

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Then would I have his Harry, and he mine.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: But let him from my thoughts. What think you, coz,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Of this young Percys pride the prisoners,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Which he in this adventure hath surprised,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: To his own use he keeps and sends me word,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: I shall have none but Mordake Earl of Fife.

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: This is his uncles teaching this is Worcester,

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Malevolent to you in all aspects

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Which makes him prune himself, and bristle up

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: The crest of youth against your dignity.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: But I have sent for him to answer this

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: And for this cause awhile we must neglect

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Our holy purpose to Jerusalem.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Cousin, on Wednesday next our council we

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Will hold at Windsor so inform the lords:

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: But come yourself with speed to us again

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: For more is to be said and to be done

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Than out of anger can be uttered.

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: I will, my liege.

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: SCENE II. London. An apartment of the Princes.

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Enter the PRINCE OF WALES and FALSTAFF

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Now, Hal, what time of day is it, lad

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Thou art so fatwitted, with drinking of old sack

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: and unbuttoning thee after supper and sleeping upon

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: benches after noon, that thou hast forgotten to

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: demand that truly which thou wouldst truly know.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: What a devil hast thou to do with the time of the

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: day Unless hours were cups of sack and minutes

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: capons and clocks the tongues of bawds and dials the

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: signs of leapinghouses and the blessed sun himself

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: a fair hot wench in flamecoloured taffeta, I see no

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: reason why thou shouldst be so superfluous to demand

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: the time of the day.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Indeed, you come near me now, Hal for we that take

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: purses go by the moon and the seven stars, and not

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: by Phoebus, he,that wandering knight so fair. And,

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: I prithee, sweet wag, when thou art king, as, God

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: save thy grace,majesty I should say, for grace

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: thou wilt have none,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: What, none

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: No, by my troth, not so much as will serve to

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: prologue to an egg and butter.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Well, how then come, roundly, roundly.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Marry, then, sweet wag, when thou art king, let not

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: us that are squires of the nights body be called

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: thieves of the days beauty: let us be Dianas

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: foresters, gentlemen of the shade, minions of the

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: moon and let men say we be men of good government,

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: being governed, as the sea is, by our noble and

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: chaste mistress the moon, under whose countenance we steal.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Thou sayest well, and it holds well too for the

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: fortune of us that are the moons men doth ebb and

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: flow like the sea, being governed, as the sea is,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: by the moon. As, for proof, now: a purse of gold

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: most resolutely snatched on Monday night and most

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: dissolutely spent on Tuesday morning got with

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: swearing Lay by and spent with crying Bring in

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: now in as low an ebb as the foot of the ladder

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: and by and by in as high a flow as the ridge of the gallows.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: By the Lord, thou sayest true, lad. And is not my

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: hostess of the tavern a most sweet wench

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: As the honey of Hybla, my old lad of the castle. And

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: is not a buff jerkin a most sweet robe of durance

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: How now, how now, mad wag! what, in thy quips and

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: thy quiddities what a plague have I to do with a

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: buff jerkin

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Why, what a pox have I to do with my hostess of the tavern

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Well, thou hast called her to a reckoning many a

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: time and oft.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Did I ever call for thee to pay thy part

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: No Ill give thee thy due, thou hast paid all there.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Yea, and elsewhere, so far as my coin would stretch

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: and where it would not, I have used my credit.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Yea, and so used it that were it not here apparent

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: that thou art heir apparentBut, I prithee, sweet

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: wag, shall there be gallows standing in England when

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: thou art king and resolution thus fobbed as it is

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: with the rusty curb of old father antic the law Do

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: not thou, when thou art king, hang a thief.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: No thou shalt.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Shall I O rare! By the Lord, Ill be a brave judge.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Thou judgest false already: I mean, thou shalt have

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: the hanging of the thieves and so become a rare hangman.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Well, Hal, well and in some sort it jumps with my

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: humour as well as waiting in the court, I can tell

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: you.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: For obtaining of suits

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Yea, for obtaining of suits, whereof the hangman

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: hath no lean wardrobe. Sblood, I am as melancholy

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: as a gib cat or a lugged bear.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Or an old lion, or a lovers lute.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Yea, or the drone of a Lincolnshire bagpipe.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: What sayest thou to a hare, or the melancholy of

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Moorditch

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Thou hast the most unsavoury similes and art indeed

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: the most comparative, rascalliest, sweet young

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: prince. But, Hal, I prithee, trouble me no more

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: with vanity. I would to God thou and I knew where a

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: commodity of good names were to be bought. An old

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: lord of the council rated me the other day in the

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: street about you, sir, but I marked him not and yet

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: he talked very wisely, but I regarded him not and

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: yet he talked wisely, and in the street too.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Thou didst well for wisdom cries out in the

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: streets, and no man regards it.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: O, thou hast damnable iteration and art indeed able

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: to corrupt a saint. Thou hast done much harm upon

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: me, Hal God forgive thee for it! Before I knew

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: thee, Hal, I knew nothing and now am I, if a man

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: should speak truly, little better than one of the

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: wicked. I must give over this life, and I will give

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: it over: by the Lord, and I do not, I am a villain:

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Ill be damned for never a kings son in

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Christendom.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Where shall we take a purse tomorrow, Jack

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Zounds, where thou wilt, lad Ill make one an I

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: do not, call me villain and baffle me.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: I see a good amendment of life in thee from praying

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: to pursetaking.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Why, Hal, tis my vocation, Hal tis no sin for a

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: man to labour in his vocation.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Enter POINS

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Poins! Now shall we know if Gadshill have set a

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: match. O, if men were to be saved by merit, what

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: hole in hell were hot enough for him This is the

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: most omnipotent villain that ever cried Stand to

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: a true man.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Good morrow, Ned.

speaker: POINS
text_entry: Good morrow, sweet Hal. What says Monsieur Remorse

speaker: POINS
text_entry: what says Sir John Sack and Sugar Jack! how

speaker: POINS
text_entry: agrees the devil and thee about thy soul, that thou

speaker: POINS
text_entry: soldest him on GoodFriday last for a cup of Madeira

speaker: POINS
text_entry: and a cold capons leg

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Sir John stands to his word, the devil shall have

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: his bargain for he was never yet a breaker of

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: proverbs: he will give the devil his due.

speaker: POINS
text_entry: Then art thou damned for keeping thy word with the devil.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Else he had been damned for cozening the devil.

speaker: POINS
text_entry: But, my lads, my lads, tomorrow morning, by four

speaker: POINS
text_entry: oclock, early at Gadshill! there are pilgrims going

speaker: POINS
text_entry: to Canterbury with rich offerings, and traders

speaker: POINS
text_entry: riding to London with fat purses: I have vizards

speaker: POINS
text_entry: for you all you have horses for yourselves:

speaker: POINS
text_entry: Gadshill lies tonight in Rochester: I have bespoke

speaker: POINS
text_entry: supper tomorrow night in Eastcheap: we may do it

speaker: POINS
text_entry: as secure as sleep. If you will go, I will stuff

speaker: POINS
text_entry: your purses full of crowns if you will not, tarry

speaker: POINS
text_entry: at home and be hanged.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Hear ye, Yedward if I tarry at home and go not,

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Ill hang you for going.

speaker: POINS
text_entry: You will, chops

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Hal, wilt thou make one

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Who, I rob I a thief not I, by my faith.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Theres neither honesty, manhood, nor good

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: fellowship in thee, nor thou camest not of the blood

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: royal, if thou darest not stand for ten shillings.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Well then, once in my days Ill be a madcap.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Why, thats well said.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Well, come what will, Ill tarry at home.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: By the Lord, Ill be a traitor then, when thou art king.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: I care not.

speaker: POINS
text_entry: Sir John, I prithee, leave the prince and me alone:

speaker: POINS
text_entry: I will lay him down such reasons for this adventure

speaker: POINS
text_entry: that he shall go.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Well, God give thee the spirit of persuasion and him

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: the ears of profiting, that what thou speakest may

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: move and what he hears may be believed, that the

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: true prince may, for recreation sake, prove a false

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: thief for the poor abuses of the time want

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: countenance. Farewell: you shall find me in Eastcheap.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Farewell, thou latter spring! farewell, Allhallown summer!

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Exit Falstaff

speaker: POINS
text_entry: Now, my good sweet honey lord, ride with us

speaker: POINS
text_entry: tomorrow: I have a jest to execute that I cannot

speaker: POINS
text_entry: manage alone. Falstaff, Bardolph, Peto and Gadshill

speaker: POINS
text_entry: shall rob those men that we have already waylaid:

speaker: POINS
text_entry: yourself and I will not be there and when they

speaker: POINS
text_entry: have the booty, if you and I do not rob them, cut

speaker: POINS
text_entry: this head off from my shoulders.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: How shall we part with them in setting forth

speaker: POINS
text_entry: Why, we will set forth before or after them, and

speaker: POINS
text_entry: appoint them a place of meeting, wherein it is at

speaker: POINS
text_entry: our pleasure to fail, and then will they adventure

speaker: POINS
text_entry: upon the exploit themselves which they shall have

speaker: POINS
text_entry: no sooner achieved, but well set upon them.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Yea, but tis like that they will know us by our

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: horses, by our habits and by every other

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: appointment, to be ourselves.

speaker: POINS
text_entry: Tut! our horses they shall not see: Ill tie them

speaker: POINS
text_entry: in the wood our vizards we will change after we

speaker: POINS
text_entry: leave them: and, sirrah, I have cases of buckram

speaker: POINS
text_entry: for the nonce, to immask our noted outward garments.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Yea, but I doubt they will be too hard for us.

speaker: POINS
text_entry: Well, for two of them, I know them to be as

speaker: POINS
text_entry: truebred cowards as ever turned back and for the

speaker: POINS
text_entry: third, if he fight longer than he sees reason, Ill

speaker: POINS
text_entry: forswear arms. The virtue of this jest will be, the

speaker: POINS
text_entry: incomprehensible lies that this same fat rogue will

speaker: POINS
text_entry: tell us when we meet at supper: how thirty, at

speaker: POINS
text_entry: least, he fought with what wards, what blows, what

speaker: POINS
text_entry: extremities he endured and in the reproof of this

speaker: POINS
text_entry: lies the jest.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Well, Ill go with thee: provide us all things

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: necessary and meet me tomorrow night in Eastcheap

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: there Ill sup. Farewell.

speaker: POINS
text_entry: Farewell, my lord.

speaker: POINS
text_entry: Exit Poins

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: I know you all, and will awhile uphold

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: The unyoked humour of your idleness:

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Yet herein will I imitate the sun,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Who doth permit the base contagious clouds

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: To smother up his beauty from the world,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: That, when he please again to be himself,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Being wanted, he may be more wonderd at,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: By breaking through the foul and ugly mists

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Of vapours that did seem to strangle him.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: If all the year were playing holidays,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: To sport would be as tedious as to work

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: But when they seldom come, they wishd for come,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: And nothing pleaseth but rare accidents.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: So, when this loose behavior I throw off

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: And pay the debt I never promised,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: By how much better than my word I am,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: By so much shall I falsify mens hopes

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: And like bright metal on a sullen ground,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: My reformation, glittering oer my fault,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Shall show more goodly and attract more eyes

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Than that which hath no foil to set it off.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Ill so offend, to make offence a skill

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Redeeming time when men think least I will.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Exit
